article.description: Zydrunas Ilgauskas, playing for the first time in nearly a year, scored 11 points and Andre Miller had a career-high 34 Tuesday night, leading the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 100-88 win over the Detroit Pistons.
article.headline: Miller has career-high 34, close to triple-double

images.name: Miller_Andre 120401 inline
images.caption: Andre Miller had a career-high 34 points, 11 assists and eight rebounds.

article.linkText: Miller's career night carries Cavs past Pistons
article.story:
CLEVELAND (AP) -- One game and one giant step forward. For Zydrunas Ilgauskas and the Cleveland Cavaliers, a win over the Detroit Pistons meant so much more. Ilgauskas, playing for the first time in nearly a year, scored 11 points and Andre Miller had a career-high 34 Tuesday night, leading the Cavs to a 100-88 win over the Pistons. The 7-foot-3 Ilgauskas, limited to just 29 games the past three years because of foot injuries, hadn't played for the Cavs since last Dec. 22 when he hurt his left foot and underwent his fifth surgery. But although he looked rusty and got winded during his 16 minutes, Ilgauskas sparked the Cavs, who have won five of their last six home games. "It's good to be back," Ilgauskas said. "It's been a long, frustrating road for me, the fans, the team and my family. I played pretty good." Miller added 11 assists, including two on key baskets in the final 2:03 as the Cavs held on. Miller went 12-of-16 from the field, added eight rebounds, three blocks, three steals and scored Cleveland's final six points on free throws. Lamond Murray had 19 points, Jumaine Jones added 14 rebounds and Chris Mihm had 10 points and 12 rebounds for the Cavs, who for a change can finally see a glimmer of hope with Ilgauskas back. Ilgauskas, who has missed 282 of a possible 396 games since being drafted in 1996, made 4 of 6 shots, blocked two and altered several others. "There was a little buzz in the crowd," said Cavs guard Wes Person. "That was great. There were a lot of smiles on a lot of faces. He does everything so well. He gives us so many dimensions." Corliss Williamson had 19 points for the Pistons, who came in leading the NBA's Central Division but played more like the squad which won just 32 games last season. Clifford Robinson added 17 points and Jerry Stackhouse 14 -- but none in the second half when he went 0-for-10 from the floor. "We ran some plays and got some looks and didn't knock them down," said Stackhouse. "Some things they were doing defensively slowed us down. We moved the ball and got some looks but we didn't knock down enough." After scoring nine points in the first half, Ilgauskas came back with 5:31 left in the third quarter and the Cavs trailing 65-64. Moments later, Bimbo Coles and Wesley Person hit consecutive 3-pointers and the Cavs went on a 16-2 run to open a 7-point lead after three. Williamson's basket gave the Pistons an 84-83 lead with 6:06 left, but Miller scored 10 points and the Cavs closed the game with a 17-4 spurt despite making seven turnovers in the final period. Ilgauskas made his debut to chants of "Z" and a standing ovation with 1:53 left in the first quarter and scored his first basket just 30 seconds later. Grabbing an entry pass near the baseline, Ilgauskas spun on the baseline, made a pump fake on Zeljko Rebraca and dropped in a short jumper. Ilgauskas admitted being a bit nervous but said once he was on the floor, he calmed down -- especially when his first shot dropped. "I was just happy it went in," he said. The next time he touched the ball, Ilgauskas drew a shooting foul and split a pair of free throws. On the defensive end, he flattened Stackhouse on a drive to the basket. He dunked, made a left-handed layup and hit a nice fadeaway jumper from 12 feet before being replaced. As he went to the bench, Cavs coach John Lucas, who had yet to coach his center in a regular-season game, slapped hands with Ilgauskas. Even the Pistons were glad to see Ilgauskas back. "Hopefully, he can stay healthy," Stackhouse said. "Just having him back, I know was an inspiration for them."

Game notes
The Cavs were 15-9 last year when Ilgauskas got hurt. They went 15-43 without him. ... The Pistons had won three straight road games. ... Lucas said he wasn't going to hand Ilgauskas his starting job back. "He's got to earn it," said Lucas, who added his biggest goal was to make sure "Z" didn't get hurt again. "This is like patchwork for "Z". Let's get him through the year and then we can talk about how dominant I think he can be." ... Pistons G Dana Barros missed his third straight game with a pulled left hamstring.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
